simulated_ratings.title: Despicable Me (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Funny, big-hearted caper with Gru and the girls that hits my family-animation sweet spot without getting too silly

simulated_ratings.feeling: A charming, warm buddy adventure that balances laughs and heart the way I like

simulated_ratings.title: Toy Story (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever, heartfelt, and endlessly inventive—exactly the kind of animated storytelling I adore

simulated_ratings.title: Grease (1978)

simulated_ratings.title: The Kissing Booth (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cliched, shrill teen antics drown out the sweetness, and the friendship stakes never feel genuine for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Moulin Rouge (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dazzling, swoony jukebox spectacle with real heart, even if the maximalist style occasionally overwhelms me.

simulated_ratings.title: Josie and the Pussycats (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bubbly and good-natured with some sly jabs, but it’s lightweight fun more than a keeper for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Malaal (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Earnest culture-clash romance with sparks, though the melodrama and length keep me at arm’s length.

simulated_ratings.title: Deconstructing The Beatles | Sgt. Peppers Lonely Hearts Club Band (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: An engaging, insightful dive into beloved music that satisfies my curiosity without getting too dry.

simulated_ratings.title: William Shakespeare's Romeo + Juliet (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Vibrant and stylish, but the Bard’s dialogue in a hyper-modern package works only in fits for me.

simulated_ratings.title: To All the Boys I've Loved Before (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sweet, sincere teen romance with a charming lead that goes down easy and leaves me smiling.

simulated_ratings.title: Flypaper (2011)

simulated_ratings.title: The Kissing Booth 2 (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: More padded teen drama and contrived dilemmas that wear out their welcome fast for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Navigator: A Mediaeval Odyssey, The (1988)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody, imaginative time-slip quest that’s odd but intriguing and quietly affecting.

simulated_ratings.title: Death Note (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cool premise, but the grim tone and messy execution sap the fun and tension for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Comets (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A tender, reflective reunion piece whose quiet ache and lived-in emotions linger nicely.

simulated_ratings.title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody, funny, and increasingly perilous—an engrossing chapter with character beats I enjoy.

simulated_ratings.title: Yellow Submarine (1968)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Whimsical, music-rich psychedelia that’s charmingly odd and buoyant, even if a bit of its magic is of its time.

simulated_ratings.title: Jonah: A VeggieTales Movie (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cute, upbeat moral tale with agreeable tunes, enjoyable if not top-tier for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Surviving Sid (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Goofy, kid-pleasing shenanigans with Sid that deliver a few chuckles and a light good time.

simulated_ratings.title: Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2 (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clumsy and unpleasant horror that loses the original’s spark and isn’t my cup of tea.

simulated_ratings.title: Rumpelstiltskin (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Well-meaning fairy-tale musical that feels creaky and uneven despite a sweet core.

simulated_ratings.title: Pride and Prejudice (1940)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Witty, breezy old-Hollywood romance that’s cozy and thoroughly charming.

simulated_ratings.title: Back to the Future Part III (1990)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A warm, playful western send-off with heart for Doc and Marty that I’m happy to ride along with.

simulated_ratings.title: The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes and Doctor Watson: The Hunt for the Tiger (1980)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Classic, low-key Holmes mystery pleasures—less flash, solid deduction, satisfying comfort viewing.

simulated_ratings.title: Freaky Friday (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Breezy, big-hearted body-swap comedy with likable performances and just enough warmth.

simulated_ratings.title: Terug Naar Morgen (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A thoughtful, tender time-bending romance whose what-if emotions outweigh the sci-fi trappings.

simulated_ratings.title: Heat, The (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Abstract and opaque rather than engaging, leaving me cool despite the promise of intensity.

simulated_ratings.title: Lucky Number (1951)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Snappy, gag-filled Donald Duck short that scratches my classic-animation itch.

simulated_ratings.title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A rousing, emotional finale that pays off the journey with heart and spectacle.

simulated_ratings.title: Pokiri (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Punchy, pulpy action with momentum, enjoyable in spots even if it’s not squarely my sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: To All the Boys: P.S. I Still Love You (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Still sweet and sincere, though the manufactured love-triangle bumps dull some of the charm.

simulated_ratings.title: Uncanny Annie (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A neat game-night premise with a few jolts, but the mean streak and TV-movie feel limit it for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A darker, slower, tense setup chapter that still works for me on character and mood.

simulated_ratings.title: The Arrival (2017)
